OFCIO’s guidance "impacts the long-term implementation strategy out in the agencies," a current OMB employee told me, and if that’s lacking, there will be "a debilitating effect on overall cybersecurity in the long run."

https://subscriber.politicopro.com/article/2019/04/turmoil-consumes-white-house-team-guiding-feds-it-strategy-1335486 …

1115648971844792320.text:
The OFCIO turmoil won't spell cyber disaster — at least not anytime soon.

Agencies have their own IT teams and can modernize/secure on their own.

But if this continues, OFCIO won't be as effective at high-level, cross-government coordination — keeping everyone rowing together.

1115648740474408961.text:
Unsurprisingly, the survey summary said that "without a substantial improvement in morale," there would be "significant challenges with retention of current staff and recruitment of new talent."

One workstream lead is leaving at the end of the month.

1115648460051615745.text:
OFCIO staff are often blindsided by policy and hiring news, per sources and survey.

They learned about Federal CISO Grant Schneider's appointment through the press.

Staff "might get a call the night before ... some major announcement and [be] asked to support it," source said.

1115648172792131585.text:
OFCIO staff complaints include:

* A reorg that confused OFCIO and its OMB/agency partners and left workstream leaders unempowered

* Federal CIO Suzette Kent's inaccessibility (no emailing her)

* Unclear priorities (can't do everything, especially when understaffed like now)

1115647806574927872.text:
In this environment, "things do slip through the cracks," an OMB employee familiar with OFCIO told me.

The employee said there was "real concern at the staff level that if this continues, something bad will happen and we won’t be ready for it."

1115647645815590913.text:
Only 19% of staff in the Office of the Federal Chief Information Officer are satisfied with work there, according to a February survey summary I obtained.

That's dramatically lower than other OMB units (per OMB-specific FEVS data I obtained) & other agencies (public FEVS data).

1115647424666787841.text:
New: The OMB office overseeing agencies' IT & cyber upgrades is plagued by abysmal morale, as staffers criticize distant leaders & a confusing reorg.

"This organization looks like it’s in free fall."

My story based on interviews & internal survey data: https://subscriber.politicopro.com/article/2019/04/turmoil-consumes-white-house-team-guiding-feds-it-strategy-1335486 …

1112720876745691136.text:
In the meantime, the EAC commissioners who lack clearances cannot review classified intelligence about election security threats on a regular basis.

They can get one-day "read-ins" for specific briefings, but that ad-hoc arrangement isn't the same thing.

1112720585640079360.text: The EAC told me that it expects Hicks and Palmer to receive their interim clearances soon. They've submitted all the paperwork. DHS, whose security office handles these clearances, wouldn't discuss their applications.

1112720373068558336.text:
Chairwoman Christy McCormick has an interim clearance, but that's new, because she's been on the EAC (without a clearance) since 2014.

The other new commissioner, Benjamin Hovland, has a permanent clearance from his previous job as a Senate staffer.

1106557919418638338.text:
State can create the new bureau without congressional permission.

It has to submit a formal congressional notification (could come next week) and wait 30 days, and a committee can issue a hold in that time, but a hold is a norm and State can ignore it (as it has in the past).

1106557422615887872.text:
Another source said State "has not provided any indication of how it will address the bipartisan concerns Congress has raised so far."

State declined to comment, saying it was still "working closely with Congress."

1106557201915826177.text: "Leaving some key cross-cutting cyber and Internet issues in a technically focused office in the economic bureau is a recipe for confusion and future turf wars rather than effective coordination and leadership," one source told me.

1106556945710891009.text:
One of Congress's lingering questions that State still hasn't answered, per my sources: If the CIP office is sticking around in the economic bureau, how will the two partner to address issues like Huawei?

State and Congress apparently see CIP's work differently.

1106556585264988161.text:

1099054351836954624.text:
So you end up in the situation we're in now, where states and cities see BMDs as the best of both worlds, security and accessibility.

Which means trusting that your barcode actually contains your vote choices — something that most experts say simply cannot be guaranteed.

1099053968184016902.text:
But many people with disabilities can't vote on plain paper ballots, and they need to be able to vote.

Election security experts encourage precincts to buy mostly paper machines, with a few BMDs for accessibility.

But some disability-rights advocates say that's discriminatory.

1099053638129995778.text: A hacker who compromises a BMD may be able to trick the machine into spitting out a piece of paper that has one set of votes contained in the barcode — which is actually tallied — and another set of votes contained in the text that voters check.

1099053122792669184.text: .@jhalderm added, "We simply don't know whether BMDs can generate a paper trail that's sufficiently hard for attackers to manipulate. They're a relatively new and untested technology."

1099052723918569474.text:
BMDs are popular b/c they appear to combine the security of paper systems w/ the accessibility of electronic ones.

But as @mattblaze told me, relying on barcodes "basically turns the system into one that has all of the well-known problems that paperless...voting machines have."
